trans-unit.source: Run Startup Tasks in Azure Cloud Services | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Run Startup Tasks in Azure Cloud Services | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Startup tasks help prepare your cloud service environment for your app. This teaches you how startup tasks work and how to make them
trans-unit.target: Startup tasks help prepare your cloud service environment for your app. This teaches you how startup tasks work and how to make them

trans-unit.source: How to configure and run startup tasks for a cloud service
trans-unit.target: How to configure and run startup tasks for a cloud service

trans-unit.source: You can use startup tasks to perform operations before a role starts.
trans-unit.target: You can use startup tasks to perform operations before a role starts.

trans-unit.source: Operations that you might want to perform include installing a component, registering COM components, setting registry keys, or starting a long running process.
trans-unit.target: Operations that you might want to perform include installing a component, registering COM components, setting registry keys, or starting a long running process.

trans-unit.source: Startup tasks are not applicable to Virtual Machines, only to Cloud Service Web and Worker roles.
trans-unit.target: Startup tasks are not applicable to Virtual Machines, only to Cloud Service Web and Worker roles.

trans-unit.source: How startup tasks work
trans-unit.target: How startup tasks work

trans-unit.source: Startup tasks are actions that are taken before your roles begin and are defined in the [ServiceDefinition.csdef] file by using the [Task] element within the [Startup] element.
trans-unit.target: Startup tasks are actions that are taken before your roles begin and are defined in the [ServiceDefinition.csdef] file by using the [Task] element within the [Startup] element.

trans-unit.source: Frequently startup tasks are batch files, but they can also be console applications, or batch files that start PowerShell scripts.
trans-unit.target: Frequently startup tasks are batch files, but they can also be console applications, or batch files that start PowerShell scripts.

trans-unit.source: Environment variables pass information into a startup task, and local storage can be used to pass information out of a startup task.
trans-unit.target: Environment variables pass information into a startup task, and local storage can be used to pass information out of a startup task.

trans-unit.source: For example, an environment variable can specify the path to a program you want to install, and files can be written to local storage that can then be read later by your roles.
trans-unit.target: For example, an environment variable can specify the path to a program you want to install, and files can be written to local storage that can then be read later by your roles.

trans-unit.source: Your startup task can log information and errors to the directory specified by the TEMP environment variable.
trans-unit.target: Your startup task can log information and errors to the directory specified by the TEMP environment variable.

trans-unit.source: During the startup task, the TEMP environment variable resolves to the
trans-unit.target: During the startup task, the TEMP environment variable resolves to the

trans-unit.source: C:\\Resources\\temp\\[guid].[rolename]\\RoleTemp directory when running on the cloud.
trans-unit.target: C:\\Resources\\temp\\[guid].[rolename]\\RoleTemp directory when running on the cloud.

trans-unit.source: Startup tasks can also be executed several times between reboots.
trans-unit.target: Startup tasks can also be executed several times between reboots.

trans-unit.source: For example, the startup task will be run each time the role recycles, and role recycles may not always include a reboot.
trans-unit.target: For example, the startup task will be run each time the role recycles, and role recycles may not always include a reboot.

trans-unit.source: Startup tasks should be written in a way that allows them to run several times without problems.
trans-unit.target: Startup tasks should be written in a way that allows them to run several times without problems.

trans-unit.source: Startup tasks must end with an errorlevel (or exit code) of zero for the startup process to complete.
trans-unit.target: Startup tasks must end with an errorlevel (or exit code) of zero for the startup process to complete.

trans-unit.source: If a startup task ends with a non-zero errorlevel, the role will not start.
trans-unit.target: If a startup task ends with a non-zero errorlevel, the role will not start.

trans-unit.source: Role startup order
trans-unit.target: Role startup order

trans-unit.source: The following lists the role startup procedure in Azure:
trans-unit.target: The following lists the role startup procedure in Azure:

trans-unit.source: The instance is marked as Starting and does not receive traffic.
trans-unit.target: The instance is marked as Starting and does not receive traffic.

trans-unit.source: All startup tasks are executed according to their taskType attribute.
trans-unit.target: All startup tasks are executed according to their taskType attribute.

trans-unit.source: The simple tasks are executed synchronously, one at a time.
trans-unit.target: The simple tasks are executed synchronously, one at a time.

trans-unit.source: The background and foreground tasks are started asynchronously, parallel to the startup task.
trans-unit.target: The background and foreground tasks are started asynchronously, parallel to the startup task.

trans-unit.source: IIS may not be fully configured during the startup task stage in the startup process, so role-specific data may not be available.
trans-unit.target: IIS may not be fully configured during the startup task stage in the startup process, so role-specific data may not be available.

trans-unit.source: Startup tasks that require role-specific data should use <link><linkText>Microsoft.WindowsAzure.ServiceRuntime.RoleEntryPoint.OnStart</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: Startup tasks that require role-specific data should use <link><linkText>Microsoft.WindowsAzure.ServiceRuntime.RoleEntryPoint.OnStart</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: The role host process is started and the site is created in IIS.
trans-unit.target: The role host process is started and the site is created in IIS.

trans-unit.source: The <link><linkText>Microsoft.WindowsAzure.ServiceRuntime.RoleEntryPoint.OnStart</linkText><title></title></link> method is called.
trans-unit.target: The <link><linkText>Microsoft.WindowsAzure.ServiceRuntime.RoleEntryPoint.OnStart</linkText><title></title></link> method is called.

trans-unit.source: The instance is marked as Ready and traffic is routed to the instance.
trans-unit.target: The instance is marked as Ready and traffic is routed to the instance.

trans-unit.source: The <link><linkText>Microsoft.WindowsAzure.ServiceRuntime.RoleEntryPoint.Run</linkText><title></title></link> method is called.
trans-unit.target: The <link><linkText>Microsoft.WindowsAzure.ServiceRuntime.RoleEntryPoint.Run</linkText><title></title></link> method is called.

trans-unit.source: Example of a startup task
trans-unit.target: Example of a startup task

trans-unit.source: Startup tasks are defined in the [ServiceDefinition.csdef] file, in the Task element.
trans-unit.target: Startup tasks are defined in the [ServiceDefinition.csdef] file, in the Task element.

trans-unit.source: The commandLine attribute specifies the name and parameters of the startup batch file or console command, the executionContext attribute specifies the privilege level of the startup task, and the taskType attribute specifies how the task will be executed.
trans-unit.target: The commandLine attribute specifies the name and parameters of the startup batch file or console command, the executionContext attribute specifies the privilege level of the startup task, and the taskType attribute specifies how the task will be executed.

trans-unit.source: In this example, an environment variable, MyVersionNumber, is created for the startup task and set to the value "1.0.0.0".
trans-unit.target: In this example, an environment variable, MyVersionNumber, is created for the startup task and set to the value "1.0.0.0".

trans-unit.source: ServiceDefinition.csdef:
trans-unit.target: ServiceDefinition.csdef:

trans-unit.source: In the following example, the Startup.cmd batch file writes the line "The current version is 1.0.0.0" to the StartupLog.txt file in the directory specified by the TEMP environment variable.
trans-unit.target: In the following example, the Startup.cmd batch file writes the line "The current version is 1.0.0.0" to the StartupLog.txt file in the directory specified by the TEMP environment variable.

trans-unit.source: The EXIT /B 0 line ensures that the startup task ends with an errorlevel of zero.
trans-unit.target: The EXIT /B 0 line ensures that the startup task ends with an errorlevel of zero.

trans-unit.source: In Visual Studio, the Copy to Output Directory property for your startup batch file should be set to Copy Always to be sure that your startup batch file is properly deployed to your project on Azure (approot\\bin for Web roles, and approot for worker roles).
trans-unit.target: In Visual Studio, the Copy to Output Directory property for your startup batch file should be set to Copy Always to be sure that your startup batch file is properly deployed to your project on Azure (approot\\bin for Web roles, and approot for worker roles).

trans-unit.source: Description of task attributes
trans-unit.target: Description of task attributes

trans-unit.source: The following describes the attributes of the Task element in the [ServiceDefinition.csdef] file:
trans-unit.target: The following describes the attributes of the Task element in the [ServiceDefinition.csdef] file:

trans-unit.source: commandLine - Specifies the command line for the startup task:
trans-unit.target: commandLine - Specifies the command line for the startup task:

trans-unit.source: The command, with optional command line parameters, which begins the startup task.
trans-unit.target: The command, with optional command line parameters, which begins the startup task.

trans-unit.source: Frequently this is the filename of a .cmd or .bat batch file.
trans-unit.target: Frequently this is the filename of a .cmd or .bat batch file.

trans-unit.source: The task is relative to the AppRoot\\Bin folder for the deployment.
trans-unit.target: The task is relative to the AppRoot\\Bin folder for the deployment.

trans-unit.source: Environment variables are not expanded in determining the path and file of the task.
trans-unit.target: Environment variables are not expanded in determining the path and file of the task.

trans-unit.source: If environment expansion is required, you can create a small .cmd script that calls your startup task.
trans-unit.target: If environment expansion is required, you can create a small .cmd script that calls your startup task.

trans-unit.source: Can be a console application or a batch file that starts a <link><linkText>PowerShell script</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: Can be a console application or a batch file that starts a <link><linkText>PowerShell script</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: executionContext - Specifies the privilege level for the startup task.
trans-unit.target: executionContext - Specifies the privilege level for the startup task.

trans-unit.source: The privilege level can be limited or elevated:
trans-unit.target: The privilege level can be limited or elevated:

trans-unit.source: limited
trans-unit.target: limited

trans-unit.source: The startup task runs with the same privileges as the role.
trans-unit.target: The startup task runs with the same privileges as the role.

trans-unit.source: When the executionContext attribute for the [Runtime] element is also limited, then user privileges are used.
trans-unit.target: When the executionContext attribute for the [Runtime] element is also limited, then user privileges are used.

trans-unit.source: elevated
trans-unit.target: elevated

trans-unit.source: The startup task runs with administrator privileges.
trans-unit.target: The startup task runs with administrator privileges.

trans-unit.source: This allows startup tasks to install programs, make IIS configuration changes, perform registry changes, and other administrator level tasks, without increasing the privilege level of the role itself.
trans-unit.target: This allows startup tasks to install programs, make IIS configuration changes, perform registry changes, and other administrator level tasks, without increasing the privilege level of the role itself.

trans-unit.source: The privilege level of a startup task does not need to be the same as the role itself.
trans-unit.target: The privilege level of a startup task does not need to be the same as the role itself.

trans-unit.source: taskType - Specifies the way a startup task is executed.
trans-unit.target: taskType - Specifies the way a startup task is executed.

trans-unit.source: simple
trans-unit.target: simple

trans-unit.source: Tasks are executed synchronously, one at a time, in the order specified in the [ServiceDefinition.csdef] file.
trans-unit.target: Tasks are executed synchronously, one at a time, in the order specified in the [ServiceDefinition.csdef] file.

trans-unit.source: When one simple startup task ends with an errorlevel of zero, the next simple startup task is executed.
trans-unit.target: When one simple startup task ends with an errorlevel of zero, the next simple startup task is executed.

trans-unit.source: If there are no more simple startup tasks to execute, then the role itself will be started.
trans-unit.target: If there are no more simple startup tasks to execute, then the role itself will be started.

trans-unit.source: If the simple task ends with a non-zero errorlevel, the instance will be blocked.
trans-unit.target: If the simple task ends with a non-zero errorlevel, the instance will be blocked.

trans-unit.source: Subsequent simple startup tasks, and the role itself, will not start.
trans-unit.target: Subsequent simple startup tasks, and the role itself, will not start.

trans-unit.source: To ensure that your batch file ends with an errorlevel of zero, execute the command EXIT /B 0 at the end of your batch file process.
trans-unit.target: To ensure that your batch file ends with an errorlevel of zero, execute the command EXIT /B 0 at the end of your batch file process.

trans-unit.source: background
trans-unit.target: background

trans-unit.source: Tasks are executed asynchronously, in parallel with the startup of the role.
trans-unit.target: Tasks are executed asynchronously, in parallel with the startup of the role.

trans-unit.source: foreground
trans-unit.target: foreground

trans-unit.source: Tasks are executed asynchronously, in parallel with the startup of the role.
trans-unit.target: Tasks are executed asynchronously, in parallel with the startup of the role.

trans-unit.source: The key difference between a foreground and a background task is that a foreground task prevents the role from recycling or shutting down until the task has ended.
trans-unit.target: The key difference between a foreground and a background task is that a foreground task prevents the role from recycling or shutting down until the task has ended.

trans-unit.source: The background tasks do not have this restriction.
trans-unit.target: The background tasks do not have this restriction.

trans-unit.source: Environment variables
trans-unit.target: Environment variables

trans-unit.source: Environment variables are a way to pass information to a startup task.
trans-unit.target: Environment variables are a way to pass information to a startup task.

trans-unit.source: For example, you can put the path to a blob that contains a program to install, or port numbers that your role will use, or settings to control features of your startup task.
trans-unit.target: For example, you can put the path to a blob that contains a program to install, or port numbers that your role will use, or settings to control features of your startup task.

trans-unit.source: There are two kinds of environment variables for startup tasks; static environment variables and environment variables based on members of the [RoleEnvironment] class.
trans-unit.target: There are two kinds of environment variables for startup tasks; static environment variables and environment variables based on members of the [RoleEnvironment] class.

trans-unit.source: Both are in the [Environment] section of the [ServiceDefinition.csdef] file, and both use the [Variable] element and name attribute.
trans-unit.target: Both are in the [Environment] section of the [ServiceDefinition.csdef] file, and both use the [Variable] element and name attribute.

trans-unit.source: Static environment variables uses the value attribute of the [Variable] element.
trans-unit.target: Static environment variables uses the value attribute of the [Variable] element.

trans-unit.source: The example above creates the environment variable MyVersionNumber which has a static value of "1.0.0.0".
trans-unit.target: The example above creates the environment variable MyVersionNumber which has a static value of "1.0.0.0".

trans-unit.source: Another example would be to create a StagingOrProduction environment variable which you can manually set to values of "staging" or "production" to perform different startup actions based on the value of the StagingOrProduction environment variable.
trans-unit.target: Another example would be to create a StagingOrProduction environment variable which you can manually set to values of "staging" or "production" to perform different startup actions based on the value of the StagingOrProduction environment variable.

trans-unit.source: Environment variables based on members of the RoleEnvironment class do not use the value attribute of the [Variable] element.
trans-unit.target: Environment variables based on members of the RoleEnvironment class do not use the value attribute of the [Variable] element.

trans-unit.source: Instead, the [RoleInstanceValue] child element, with the appropriate xPath attribute value, are used to create an environment variable based on a specific member of the [RoleEnvironment] class.
trans-unit.target: Instead, the [RoleInstanceValue] child element, with the appropriate xPath attribute value, are used to create an environment variable based on a specific member of the [RoleEnvironment] class.

trans-unit.source: Values for the xPath attribute to access various [RoleEnvironment] values can be found in xPath Values in Azure.
trans-unit.target: Values for the xPath attribute to access various [RoleEnvironment] values can be found in xPath Values in Azure.

trans-unit.source: For example, to create an environment variable that is "true" when the instance is running in the compute emulator, and "false" when running in the cloud, use the following [Variable] and [RoleInstanceValue] elements:
trans-unit.target: For example, to create an environment variable that is "true" when the instance is running in the compute emulator, and "false" when running in the cloud, use the following [Variable] and [RoleInstanceValue] elements:

trans-unit.source: Next steps
trans-unit.target: Next steps

trans-unit.target: Learn how to perform some <link><linkText>common startup tasks</linkText><title></title></link> with your Cloud Service.

trans-unit.source: <link><linkText>Package</linkText><title></title></link> your Cloud Service.
trans-unit.target: <link><linkText>Package</linkText><title></title></link> your Cloud Service.

trans-unit.source: test
trans-unit.target: test
